block.p: It is an irony that the modern pentathlon, the one event created by the founder of the modern Games, Baron Pierre de Coubertin, receives little recognition in the United States.
Since 1912, the event has been a prestigious one for Europeans, with its unusual combination of riding, swimming, cross-country running, fencing and shooting.
It is an irony that the modern pentathlon, the one event created by the founder of the modern Games, Baron Pierre de Coubertin, receives little recognition in the United States.
Since 1912, the event has been a prestigious one for Europeans, with its unusual combination of riding, swimming, cross-country running, fencing and shooting.
Even though a fellow named George S. Patton competed, and finished fifth, for the United States 80 years ago (before he became a famous general), it hasn't caught on.

"In Eastern Europe, they look at the pentathlon as having the greatest athletes," said MIKE GOSTIGIAN, a member of the United States team from Newtown Square, Pa., "I think it makes you the most versatile athlete."

DOUG STULL of Silver Spring, Md., another American participant, said, referring to his college days: "At Texas, we used to razz the decathletes over who was really the better athlete. We said we were."
Stull was in third place after the fencing competition yesterday.
